description: From Middle English riot (“debauched living, dissipation”), from Old French riote (“debate”), from rioter (“to quarrel”), perhaps related to riboter or from Latin rugio (“I roar”).
Compare French riotte and Occitan riòta.

entries.meaning: A tumultuous disturbance of the public peace by a large group of people, often involving violence or damage to property.
examples: The protests began peacefully but turned into riots after several days.
In summer this flower garden is a riot of colour.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, uncountable) A humorous or entertaining event or person.
Wanton or unrestrained behavior or emotion.
(obsolete) Excessive and expensive feasting; wild and loose festivity; revelry.

verbs.description: riot (third-person singular simple present riots, present participle rioting, simple past and past participle rioted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To create or take part in a riot; to raise an uproar or sedition.
examples: The nuclear protesters rioted outside the military base.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To act in an unrestrained or wanton manner; to indulge in excess of feasting, luxury, etc.
(transitive) To cause to riot; to throw into a tumult.
